questions.question_text: Why must you not drive extra slowly for no reason?

options.a: Because it encourages vehicle drivers behind to perform dangerous overtaking maneuvers.
options.b: Because it causes the engine to carbonize and increases fuel consumption.
options.c: Because it is a requirement to maintain at least 80% of the posted speed limit at all times.

questions.explanation: Driving too slowly without reason obstructs the flow of traffic, increases the danger of rear-end collisions, and provokes other drivers into risky overtaking. (Book Page 13)

questions.question_text: You are driving on the Highway in fog and have only 50m visibility. What is the maximum speed you may drive?
questions.explanation: The specific safety regulation for heavy fog states that if visibility is limited to 50m, your maximum speed must not exceed 50 km/h. (Book Page 22)

questions.question_text: What must you reckon with in this residential situation?

options.a: The roadway narrowing due to improperly parked commercial vehicles.
options.b: Children may suddenly appear from between the vehicles.
options.c: The parked vehicles may suddenly reverse without using hazard lights.

questions.explanation: In residential areas with parked cars, you must always anticipate that children or pedestrians could step onto the roadway from behind the visual obstruction of the vehicles. (Book Page 13)

questions.question_text: Where is it permitted to flash your headlights to indicate your intention to overtake?

options.a: Only when driving in daylight outside built-up areas.
options.b: Inside built-up areas to warn pedestrians of your speed.
options.c: At any time on the Highway regardless of the time of day.

questions.explanation: Flashing headlights (the optical warning signal) to indicate overtaking is permitted outside built-up areas. The manual marks daylight as the primary condition for this use. (Book Page 18)

questions.question_text: Your vehicle has broken down on the Highway and is being towed. What must you remember?

options.a: Only the towed vehicle must have its hazard warning lights switched on.
options.b: During towing, both vehicles must have their hazard warning lights switched on.
options.c: Hazard lights must be replaced by a red flag on the towing rope.

questions.explanation: For safety on high-speed roads, both the towing vehicle and the vehicle being towed are required to use hazard warning lights. (Book Page 12)

questions.question_text: What is the minimum distance that should normally be maintained from the vehicle in front outside built-up areas?

options.a: The full speedometer reading in metres.
options.b: A fixed distance of 3 car lengths at all speeds.

questions.explanation: The rule of thumb for safe distance outside built-up areas is half the speedometer value (e.g., at 100km/h, maintain 50m). (Book Page 17)

questions.question_text: Why must the safe distance maintained be much greater on a wet roadway than on a dry roadway?

options.b: Because the contact between the tyres and the roadway deteriorates the rubber.
options.c: Because wheel-spray improves the efficiency of the braking system.

questions.explanation: Reduced friction on wet surfaces means the car takes longer to stop. Therefore, a larger gap is required for safety. (Book Page 13)

questions.question_text: What must the driver of the white car reckon with on this bend?

options.a: Game animals could suddenly appear from the forest on the right.
options.b: The road surface will suddenly change to gravel.
options.c: Oncoming traffic may cut the corner.

questions.explanation: On narrow or blind bends, motorists must always anticipate that oncoming vehicles might cross the center line to 'shorten' the curve. (Book Page 20)

questions.question_text: What is the recommended speed that applies to cars and motorcycles on the Highway?
questions.explanation: The manual specifically lists 130 km/h as the recommended speed for light vehicles on the Highway, provided conditions are favorable. (Book Page 11)

questions.question_text: Which motor vehicles may freely choose their lane inside built-up areas?

options.a: All motor vehicles with a permissible total mass of up to (( 3.5 )) t.
options.c: All motor vehicles regardless of mass, provided they are in a traffic jam.

questions.explanation: Inside built-up areas, vehicles with a total mass up to 3.5 tonnes are permitted to choose the lane that best suits their destination. (Book Page 9)

questions.question_text: What could cause a fast travelling motor vehicle suddenly to veer sideways on a dry straight road?

options.b: The engine stalling due to a faulty battery.
options.c: The driver switching from 5th gear to 4th gear too quickly.

questions.explanation: A sudden tyre failure (burst) creates an immediate drag on one side, forcing the vehicle to veer. (Book Page 21)

questions.question_text: The road is muddy for a short distance. What should you avoid here, if possible?

options.a: Driving with your hands in the 10-to-2 position.

questions.explanation: Sudden steering movements on mud can break traction immediately and cause a skid. (Book Page 14)

questions.question_text: With which road users must special care be taken?

options.c: Drivers of heavy goods vehicles exceeding 7.5 t.

questions.explanation: Children and the elderly are categorized as vulnerable road users requiring extra caution due to potentially limited traffic awareness or mobility. (Book Page 18)

questions.question_text: What is the maximum speed at which you are allowed to drive a car with a trailer on the Highway?
questions.explanation: The legal limit for a car towing a trailer on the Highway is 80 km/h.

questions.question_text: Why does environmentally friendly driving have a beneficial effect on traffic safety?

options.a: Because it relies on coasting in neutral while driving round bends.
options.b: Because it avoids high speeds so that dangerous situations occur less frequently.
options.c: Because it requires frequent use of the horn to clear traffic.

questions.explanation: By driving moderately and anticipating traffic (eco-driving), you reduce speed, which naturally lowers the risk and severity of accidents. (Book Page 21)
